chargeHist.descr: Impersonating a Peace Officer to Aid in Commission of Crime

result.execSummary:
The defendant Benjamin David Ogas was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Impersonating a Peace Officer to Aid in Commission of Crime, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.70(1)(a).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).
  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Racine County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes: Statutory costs assessed.   If supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.

No alcohol or controlled substances except by prescription. Random UA's are authorized. Any counseling deemed appropriate by agent; specifically AODA assessment, treatment and after care. Must continue with psychological counseling as recommended  by physician or UW Mental Health. Must be compliant in taking all medications prescribed. No contact with any minor under the age of 18 without approval of agent and parent or legal guardian. May not possess any police like equipment; badges, uniforms, handcuffs or things of that nature. No contact with the victims.   Defendant must submit a DNA sample as required by law and pay mandatory DNA surcharge. Firearm warning given. Voting is prohibited until sentence is complete and civil rights have been restored. Defendant must obey all rules and regulations while on supervision.

timeConds.notes: AMENDED 05-01-2017:  Defendant shall serve conditional jail time until he begins the AODA Residential Treatment Program at the Milwaukee Secure Detention Facility on May 25, 2017.  No huber.

Defendant Benjamin David Ogas in court with attorney Gretchen G. Rosenke.  Robert Scott Repischak appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court Reporter: Maggie Techert.
The State is in compliance with Ch. 950. Parties have reviewed PSI. No additions or corrections noted by the State. Defense puts corrections on the record.  On Ct 1, w/held sent - 4 yrs prob; Cts 2 & 8-6 mos I/S - 2 yrs prob, Ct 3-90 days I/S - 2 yrs probation. In the event that deft is revoked, all I/S time to run consec to each other. Conditions to include; taking meds as prescribed and follow through with directions of medical personnel, emp to the best of his ability, no contact with named victim, no unsupervised contact with minors not including family members, not to possess 'police equipment'; fake badges, handcuffs, etc. 6 mos RCJ as condition of probation with CFTS.
